document.docAuthor: Vink, Cor J., Dupérré, Nadine, Paquin, Pierre, Fitzgerald, Brian M. & Sirvid, Phil J.
document.masterDocTitle: The cosmopolitan spider Cryptachaea blattea (Urquhart 1886) (Araneae: Theridiidae): Redescription, including COI sequence, and new synonymy

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The cosmopolitan spider Cryptachaea blattea (Urquhart 1886) (Araneae: Theridiidae): Redescription, including COI sequence, and new synonymy

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–6.
Cryptachaea blattea (Urquhart 1886)
. 1. Habitus of female, dorsal view; 2. Female abdomen, lateral view, small tubercle arrowed; 3. Epigynum, ventral view; 4. Internal genitalia, dorsal view; 5. Male pedipalp, ventral view; 6. Male abdomen, dorsal view. Scale bars for figures 1, 2, 6 = 1.0 mm, 3–5 = 0.1 mm. Abbreviations used: E, embolus; C, conductor; T, tegulum; Cy, cymbium; S, spermathecae.

Te Karaka [
37 ° 5 'S
,
174 ° 52 'E

Theridium setiger
. Not examined.

: Auckland:

37 ° 5 'S
,

37 ° 5 'S

Monterey [
36 ° 36 'N
,
121 ° 53 'W
],
October 1945

Holotype Ψ,
Achaearanea teja
. Examined.
CHILE : Provincia de Valdivia:
Isla Teja [
39 ° 47 'S
,
73 ° 16 'W
], Valdivia, on farmland,
6 March 1965
, coll. H.W. Levi ( MCZ ).

The types of
Theridium blatteus
and
T. setiger
are not in CMNZ where all of Urquhart's existing types specimens are housed (
Court & Forster 1988
;
Nicholls et al. 2000
; Paquin et al. 2008 ). They are also not in the Otago Museum, Dunedin, New Zealand , which houses New Zealand's largest collection of spiders (C. Fraser, personal communication). We consider the types of
T. blatteus
and
T. setiger
lost. Although we weren’t able to examine the types of
T. blatteus
and
T. setiger
, the illustrations and descriptions (
Urquhart 1886
) are adequate enough to be sure of the species’ identity.

Diagnosis.
Cryptachaea blattea
can be distinguished from other
Cryptachaea
species by the epigynum of the female, which has a protruding knob with a circular opening on the anterior surface (
Fig. 3
) and the arrangement of the male pedipalp, particularly the shape of the short embolus, which lies against the conductor (
Fig. 5
).

Dimensions (mm). Female Wellington, Stokes Valley (male Wellington, Stokes Valley): total length 2.25 (1.72); carapace length 0.71 (0.80), width 0.62 (0.73), height 0.27 (0.24); abdomen length 1.54 (0.92), width 1.20 (0.80); sternum length 0.47 (0.44), width 0.36 (0.42). Size range: female body length 2.2–3.2, male body length 1.7–2.4.

Distribution. New Zealand (South Canterbury, Mid Canterbury, Marlborough Sounds, Nelson, Wellington, Taranaki, Bay of Plenty, Coromandel, Auckland), Chile (Provincia de Valdivia, Provincia de Concepción, Provincia de Quillota), USA (Hawaii, California, Washington), Canada (British Columbia ), Saint Helena , Republic of Cape Verde , Portugal (Porto, Azores, Madeira), Belgium .
Borges and Wunderlich ( 2008 )
noted that
C. blattea
was found in Colorado, but this is likely to be a typographical error and should have been recorded as California (P.A.V. Borges, personal communication). We record
C. blattea
for the first time from Australia (New South Wales and Norfolk Island ).
